active_learning.discussion_prompt: In what scenarios could discount code stacking testing be considered a legitimate penetration test versus fraudulent activity? Debate the ethical boundaries using real-world e-commerce examples like Black Friday promotions, considering authorization, intent, and potential business impact.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Pair students: One student explains the technical exploit of discount code stacking using Burp Suite (e.g., parameter tampering demo), while the other teaches a mitigation strategy (e.g., server-side validation and session tracking). Switch roles and provide feedback on clarity and accuracy.
active_learning.problem_solving: Provide a vulnerable web app scenario (e.g., DVWA or a Dockerized e-commerce simulator). Students must: 1) Identify potential stacking points in the transaction flow; 2) Exploit using Burp Suite; 3) Calculate potential fraud loss (e.g., 50%+ discount on $1000 order); 4) Report findings with remediation recommendations. Extend to real-world ethical hacking reports.

distractor_protocol.step: Generate 3 plausible distractors per card: 1) Common misconception (e.g., confuse stacking with price tampering), 2) Partial truth (e.g., client-side only fix), 3) Unrelated vuln/tool (e.g., SQLi or Wireshark).
Base on voter suggestions (e.g., ethics boundaries, tool misuse) and research (e.g., OWASP links).
Ensure distractors test deeper understanding, not trivia.
